description.en: This course examines the background of contemporary Russian foreign policy and the mechanisms of policy-making. The first part discusses theoretical approaches to Russian foreign policy, reviews the major sources and factors of foreign policy formation, looking into the most significant directions of practical foreign policy-making over the last 10-15 years.  The second part of the course is structured as a series of case studies and maps the current foreign policy debate, focusing on official doctrines, institutions and mechanisms of foreign-policy making.
description.et: Kursus vaatleb tänapäeva Venemaa välispoliitikat ning poliitikategemise mehhanisme. Esmalt käsitletakse Venemaa välispoliitika analüüsimise teoreetilisi seisukohti,  keskendutakse välispoliitika aluseks olevatele ametlikele doktriinidele, institutsioonidele ja mehhanismidele. Kursuse teises osa koosneb viimase 10-15 aasta erinevatele juhtumiuuringutele.

objectives.en: The aim of the course is to provide the students with necessary theoretical and empirical background for the analysis of Russian foreign policy. It addresses the issues of national identity, conceptual and institutional foundations of foreign policy-making, and focuses on certain key dimensions of foreign policy practice in the last 10-15 years.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärgiks on anda üliõpilastele piisavad teoreetilised ja empiirilised teadmised Venemaa välispoliitika analüüsimiseks. Kursuse käigus käsitletakse küsimusi nagu rahvuslik identiteet ning välispoliitika kujundamise kontseptuaalsed ja institutsionaalsed alused, ja keskendutakse valitud välispoliitika aspektidele viimase 10-15 aasta jooksul.

learning_outcomes.en: Upon completion of the course, the students will be able to:
1) describe, analyse and evaluate historical and ideological background of contemporary Russian foreign policy;
learning_outcomes.et: - oskab kirjeldada, analüüsida ja hinnata tänapäeva Venemaa välispoliitika ajaloolist ja ideoloogilist tausta;

learning_outcomes.en: 2) understand the relationship between Russian foreign policy and identity politics;
learning_outcomes.et: - mõistab suhet Venemaa välispoliitika ja identiteedipoliitika vahel;

learning_outcomes.en: 3) analyse main factors, decision-making patterns and policy issues of Russian foreign policy in both problem-oriented and region-specific aspects;
learning_outcomes.et: - oskab analüüsida peamisi tegureid, otsusetegemise mustreid ja poliitikaküsimusi Venemaa välispoliitikas;

learning_outcomes.en: 4) use most important sources and documents on Russian foreign policy;
learning_outcomes.et: - oskab kasutada kõige olulisemaid allikad Venemaa välispoliitika analüüsimiseks;

learning_outcomes.en: 5) critically assess the current foreign policy events and debates both within and outside Russia.
learning_outcomes.et: - suudab kriitiliselt hinnata tänaseid välispoliitilisi sündmusi ja seisukohti nii Venemaal kui väljaspool.

independent_work.et: Independent study for this course involves fulfilling the reading assignments, attending classes and participating in seminars

description.en:
Before each seminar students are invited to submit two questions or answers on the theme of seminar. Each student is expected to submit the respective materials on Moodle minimum three days before the class meeting (deadlines will be specified in designated Forums).
Students' questions will always be discussed anonymously, with no mention of the author of the question. The final allocation of points for each week will depend on the classroom discussions.
Grading will be based on two components:
1. The depth and relevance of Forum posts. The total length of each submission will be limited to 200  words.  Assessment criteria for each seminar will be provided on Moodle (5 points). 
2. The active participation in the seminar discussions. The primary goal is to ask questions and actively engage in discussion, rather than striving to provide 'correct' answers or merely reiterating ideas from documents or research papers (5 points).
The participation  is assessed according to the following criteria:
- Ability to work in team
- Capacity to take independent decisions
- Ability to discuss in group and to present motivated arguments
- Capacity to present arguments and points of view
Attendance is mandatory. If you are unable to attend due to medical reasons or with prior agreement with the instructor, you can compensate by submitting an individual assignment. The topic must also be chosen in advance in consultation with the instructor. This makeup work must be submitted within one week of the missed class. Missed assignments cannot be made up at the end of the semester.

description.en:
The final  exam will be held at the end of the course. Exam assignments will contain three open-ended questions, of which students will need to choose and answer two.
Exam papers must demonstrate sufficient knowledge of all course materials, including lectures, classroom discussions and compulsory readings, as well as being up to date with the current events. Analytical skills appropriate for a Master-level student and the ability to construct and present a logically coherent argument are also essential. Answers must focus on the assignment; additional points and observations are welcome but must not substitute or obscure the answer to the question. The answer must feature a short conclusion summarising the argument.

grade_evaluation.en:
Final grade for the course is composed of:
Seminars - max 50 points, max 10 points each seminar (50% of the final grade)

Final exam - max 50 points (50% of the final grade)
50 points - The required minimum criteria are achieved, not only formally, but also substantially; the totality of the aspects of the task are met. The answer well developed and present a remarkably high level of sophistication in their arguments and consistency. 
40 points – The required criteria are achieved, not only formally, but also substantially; almost the totality of the aspects of the task are met. The answer presents a very high level of sophistication. The analytical part and its research component, appear highly developed and satisfactory, and present only very marginal weakness that does not affect the final result. 
30 points –The required minimum criteria are achieved, not only formally, but also substantially; the answer presents a good level of sophistication. The analytical part and its (generally satisfactory) research component, appear well developed, but still present some weakness at times. 
20 points – The required minimum criteria are achieved; the formal aspects of the task are, generally, met; the answer presents a satisfactory level of development; however, the analytical part and its research component present appear basic, inconsistent, and underdeveloped in most of the parts. 
10 points - The required minimum criteria are generally achieved; the formal aspects of the task are, on the whole, met; the answer presents a sufficient level of development; however, analytical part is non-existent or clearly underdeveloped.

debt_elimination.et:
The grade for the course idepends on the timely completion of all assignments. Points for the seminar can only be earned by doing the assignment on time. Any deadlines can only be extended in case of a major emergency.
Writing additional work to increase the number of points is not allowed.
